direction.raw_text: THE WAR YEARS - DAY It is a bright sunny day on a crowded street on the black side of Boston. PEOPLE and KIDS are busy with their own things. SHORTY bops his way down the street. He is a runty, very dark young man of 21 with a mission and a smile on his face. He wears the flamboyant style of the time: the whole zoot-suit, pegged legs and a wide brim hat with a white feather stuck in the hat band. 2
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREET - DAY FOLLOW SHOT. Shorty dodges through the crowd with his packages. His smile is one of anticipation. He nods to a PAL without stopping; eyes a COUPLE OF CHICKS dancing on the street, but is not dissuaded. 6
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shorty has his jacket and hat off, his sleeves rolled up. He is like a surgeon preparing for an operation. His equipment is spread out on a table: can of lye, large mason jar, wooden stirring spoon, knife, the eggs. His actions have the character of a ritual: each thing being done just so, in time-honored fashion. He slices the potatoes and drops the thin slices into the mason jar. He adds water and makes a paste of the starch. Behind Shorty is a spirited barbershop conversation. ONE MAN is getting a haircut; TWO OTHERS are watching (TOOMER, JASON) one of them from behind a newspaper. A middle-aged barber, CHOLLY, is doing most of the talking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After I hit the number that woman wasn't no good to me at all. The men laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Shorty pries open the can of lye, whiffs it. It's good and strong. He pours some in the mason jar, stirring with the wooden spoon. He cracks the eggs into the mixture and stirs. He waits as fumes rise and feels the outside of the jar as it gets hot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - The barbershop SEEN from a door, slightly ajar. A woolly head, entirely in shadow, peers out. CHOLLY'S VOICE She says I'm cheap cuz I won't cop her a diamond ring. Had the indignation to call me a cheap black sunovabitch to boot.

direction.raw_text: And when a black woman call you a cheap black sunovabitch you've been called a cheap black sunovabitch. Cholly is annoyed. It's _his_ story. CHOLLY Will you let me tell it?

direction.raw_text: Malcolm gulps, his eyes on the fuming mason jar. Shorty starts massaging a great quantity of Vaseline into Malcolm's scalp, covering his neck and ears as well. All the men have gathered around, involved in the ritual. For Malcolm it is closer to being a kind of execution.

direction.raw_text: I thought you said it was gonna sting... this ain't nothin'. For a moment nothing happens, then the heat hits him. He yells, tries to catch his breath: his head is on fire.

direction.raw_text: You motherfucker.  You're killing me. I'm burning up. My damn head is on fire. He nearly leaps out of the chair, but the barber restrains him. Shorty, utterly unmoved by the outburst, continues working the congolene into his hair. Malcolm breaks out of the chair wildly. But the three men drag him to a basin where Shorty has attached the shower spray. His cries filling the room, Malcolm is ducked under the spray. Shorty starts rinsing out his hair.

direction.raw_text: Don't fight me, man. Let me git it out. Malcolm is a little relieved, he tentatively opens his eyes, then he feels the congolene again and there is another outburst. Shorty forces his head under the spray, spurts the water all over his head, wetting Malcolm and the shop in the process. 7

direction.raw_text: . CLOTHING STORE - DAY SHORTY Well, Homeboy, you almost there. Turn around. Shorty is supervising as Malcolm tries on a zoot suit. He slips into the jacket... Shoes-off, Malcolm steps into the tight-fltting peg-legged pants ...... dons a wide-brimmed hat with a bright blue feather.... Finally, fully outfitted, he leans forward toward his new image in the full-length mirror, twirling a long, dangling key chain.

ROXBURY STREET - DAY Malcolm and Shorty come strutting down the street: two conked, zoot-suited sharpies. Hometown boy has departed. And the CHICKS on the street notice them, especially Malcolm, the taller of the two, the lighter-skinned, the more dominant. They walk imperiously past, fully aware of their impact.

The music is WILD, the dancing is frantic, the clothes are OUT, and the crowd is predominately BLACK, although there is a peppering of WHITES, especially white chicks. direction.raw_text: are on the floor, dancing wildly. They are quickly joined by a half dozen OTHERS. These are the best dancers and constitute the main event of a Saturday night black dance. People crowd and push to get better vantage points and the competition is under way.

direction.raw_text: It is dominantly black, but there are some whites in the audience, mostly women. One is SOPHIA, a spectacular blonde with a degree of refinement, something of a thrill-seeker. Many of the men try to catch her eye, but for the moment Sophia is just watching, looking for no one in particular, but nonetheless looking.

Their advent is greeted with cheers and ad libs. Clearly the crowd has its favorites. WIDER SHOT The music gets faster and the dancing takes on a more frantic and more remarkable quality. direction.raw_text: . Laura and Malcolm are, in the phrase, cooking on all burners now; and when they execute an especially intricate step, even Hamp waves over. Malcolm is sweating and flushed and enormously elated. He sees that people are watching him, goading him on. He notices that Sophia, in particular, has not taken her eyes off him; she is clapping in time to his steps. Seeing new stars in the making, the other dancers move to the side of the floor, marking time, yielding the dance floor to them. Laura and Malcolm go into a solo.

The finale is the classic drag, with Laura hanging limp around Malcolm's neck as he capers off the dance floor to the spontaneous applause of the audience. The line of PRISONERS stands in front of their cells, as two guards, WILKINS and BARNES, one white, one black, slowly walk past the P.M. check. The procedure is routine, done without emotion, as it is done three times a day: the black guard calls out the prisoner's name, the prisoner answers with his number, then steps into his cell. Whereupon the white guard slams the door shut and locks it.

direction.raw_text: . SHOOTING PAST MALCOLM, FAVORING TWO OTHER PRISONERS. The guards are approaching Malcolm's cell. Past Malcolm are two experienced PRISONERS who have been watching Malcolm during the scene. They whisper surreptitiously without moving their bodies, and barely moving their lips. One of the prisoners is PETE, a huge barrel of a man, a lifer -- beaten by the system and a lifetime of incarceration. The other is BEMBRY, a man of no great physicality, but who possesses immediately the gift of leadership. It is clear that Pete and others look up to him with great respect.

direction.raw_text: Malcolm stands with bowed head as the hot water cascades over his broken body. He lets it run and run, but it cannot really touch his problems. On a nearby bench are his clothes, his towel and the makings for a conk: lye, Vaseline, comb, etc. He turns for a moment as he sees he is being watched by someone. It's Bembry standing nearby. Malcolm turns away, trying to find solace in the water. He wants no part of the world or anyone, just to be left alone.

Malcolm is also copying the dictionary in a school book word for word. 114

direction.raw_text: #7 - NIGHT The SAME WOMAN, now at a Muslim meeting. The faces of other listeners (from the church and from the maids' market) are scattered in Malcolm's audience. The headquarters itself shows the progress Malcolm has made. It is better furnished, larger, and the chairs are filled. Bembry, Sidney, and Lorraine are in the back of the room, pleased with the growth. Malcolm stands at a podium.

direction.raw_text: We're not American, we're Africans who happen to be in America. We were kidnapped and brought here against our will from Africa. We didn't land on Plymouth Rock, brothers and sister. Plymouth Rock landed on us. Reactions: laughter, interest. Ad lib "That's the truth."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Put an end to your begging. No more "Please, Mr. White Man, Lawdy boss, brush me another crumb from off your table, kindly, sir."  We are a nation, a great nation and don't need a thing from them. Malcolm scanning the faces of his audience as they react. He sees someone he knows and blurts out boyishly (and winningly):
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shorty! The crowd turns to Shorty, sitting embarrassedly in the audience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on up here, man, and give us some skin. Here's a man, brothers and sisters, who shot up with me, who robbed with me, and did time in the white devil's jailhouse. Stand up, Shorty, and be counted-- But Shorty is trying to hide from the spotlight. Malcolm comes down from the platform and walks to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Folks, the brother is shy and needs special attention. So would you excuse us, while Brothers Sidney and Earl take up the collection. He embraces Shorty as the crowd laughs appreciatively and Brothers Sidney and Earl have a chuckle themselves. 133
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shortly and Malcolm sit at a table. Shorty has a cup of coffee in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got to hand it to you, Homey. That's the best preacher hype I ever did hear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It isn't a hype, Shorty. And I meant what I said: join us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, baby. I don't pay that shit no mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Honorable Elijah Muhammad says you should pay it all your mind. If you got a mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Baby, I love you. Take it easy, greasy. How about a snort?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been clean for twelve years, Shorty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You is something, Homeboy. My trouble is -- I ain't had enough stuff yet, I ain't et all the ribs I want and I sure ain't had enough white tail yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's the rest of the gang? You seen anyone?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Sammy's dead. Yeah, fell over in the bed with a chick twenty years younger than him. Had twenty-five grand in his pocket. 133A
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: FLASH - Sammy, he's dead on top of TEENAGE WHORE who is screaming, trying to push that dead weight off her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about Old Cadillac? 133B
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: FLASH - Cadillac is an old junkie, past reclaiming, sitting staring in a MENTAL WARD, twitching, nose running.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooked on horse. Been in and out of Lexington Ave times.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You seen Sophia? 133C
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: FLASH - Sophia is a bored housewife, she's in the kitchen cooking while her husband hides behind the Wall Street Journal. 133D BACK TO THE BAR SHORTY I ain't seen Archie, but the vine tells it he's living somewhere's in the Bronx. If you can call it living. 134
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A knock on the door rouses Archie, by now an old and dying man. All the vigor is gone, all the life has ebbed out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Git the hell away, you bitch, I'll pay you tomorrow. Door opens, Malcolm enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Archie. Archie sits up from his bed and stares. He tries to bring back some of his old juice, tries to stand up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My man, Red. Come on in, man. (then giving up) Hey, I can't make it. Malcolm has to help him lie back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take it easy, baby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That really you, Red? The contrast is shocking: Malcolm tall and straight; Archie ruined.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You saved my life, Archie. Running me out of Harlem. When I think how close we came to gunning each other down, I have to thank Allah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wasn't gonna shoot you, baby. It was just my rep, that's all. And don't shit me now, but did you have that number? Tell me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. It doesn't matter. The thing is we got to get you back on your feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. I got a couple a new angles ain't been figured yet. All I need's a stake and a chance--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you use a few bucks? I ain't got much, but--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, man, I'm doing okay. Thanks. MALCOLM Take it easy. Lay down and don't think about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You could of been something, Archie, but the devil got to you. The old man is asleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know all the angles except how to live. 135         EXT. A STREET IN HARLEM - NIGHT Malcolm walks thoughtfully down the street; Archie is still on his mind, as he passes prostitute after prostitute. Once beautiful women now selling their bodies. He passes Laura, she has been turned totally out and she looks the part, there is no way he can recognize her. We do though. CLOSE - LAURA She has just gotten a white John and leads him into an alley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Women who could be mothers, teachers, scientists...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laura kneels down to unzip her John's pants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is going to raise our children?; men who might have been astronauts, composers, engineers; Who is going to be the head of the households?-- 136
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: #7 - NIGHT Malcolm is addressing a HUGE AUDIENCE. His tone is more intense, more personal than before, because of his recent encounters. In the audience, sitting with Bembry, is BETTY, a lovely dark-skinned woman. Her interest in Malcolm (true, also, for most of the other unmarried sisters) is more than religious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: --and what has the white devil made of them: dead souls. Oh, my he has no conscience. He should fall on his knees and say, "My kind commits history's greatest crime against your kind every day of your life." But does he? No. He scorns you, splits your head with his nightstick and calls you nigger. If you've had it, then stand up and come forward. If not us, then who? If not now, then when?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Many stand, some walk toward the podium speaking his name: "I'm with you, Brother Malcolm," "Praise Allah," "Me, Brother Malcolm." There is applause; some of the audience get to their feet -- Malcolm acknowledges their approval, trying to quiet them, but caught up in the heady excitement of leadership.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Both are moved by Malcolm's performances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He ought to try to make it a little easier, Brother Bembry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you try telling him that, Sister Betty? 137
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: #7 - NIGHT The Muslim movement has grown enormously. The activity in this anteroom, leading to other rooms off it, shows that. Betty and Bembry stand before a Directory announcing activities in the Temple: MONDAY - Fruit of Islam Meeting; TUESDAY - Unity Night; WEDNESDAY - Student Enrollment; THURSDAY - Muslim Girls Training; FRIDAY - General Civilization Class; SATURDAY - Swahili, etc. A stir of people and activity as Malcolm enters the anteroom. He excuses himself from a group of MUSLIMS, making his way toward Bembry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brother Bembry, can we fix it so our loudspeaker is heard on the street?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure we can. This is a new sister, Sister Betty. Malcolm nods at her; she nods in return.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Sister lectures our Muslim women in hygiene and diet. Malcolm mutters "very good," but his mind is clearly on a million other details.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Sister stresses care of the body and regular eating habits. Malcolm is still distracted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Sister wonders if the Brother knows what Harriet Tubman did between taking souls to the Promised Land? Malcolm is stopped. He looks at Betty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She ate. Malcolm laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the Sister suggests he put his actions where his mouth is. Malcolm's laughter is heard, in response. 138
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure I'll speak to your class. But I'm a hard man on women. You want to know why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you want to tell me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Malcolm sits next to the Honorable Elijah Muhammad. The student and the teacher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you want to tell me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Women are deceitful. They are untrustworthy flesh. I've seen too many men ruined or tied down or messed up by women.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Betty says nothing, she merely pushes the salad plate a little toward him. The food has thus far gone untouched. Malcolm continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Women talk too much. To tell a woman not to talk is like telling Jesse James not to carry a gun or a hen not to cackle. And Samson, the strongest man that ever lived, was destroyed by the woman who slept in his arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shall I tell my sisters that we oppose marriage?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. We are not Catholic priests. We do not practice celibacy. If a woman is the right height for a man, the right complexion, if her age is half the man's plus seven, if she understands that man's essential nature is strong and woman's weak, if she loves children, can cook, sew and stay out of trouble--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think you've made your points, Brother Malcolm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What points?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That you haven't time for either marriage or eating-- Malcolm chuckles a bit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: --and that women aren't the only ones who talk a lot. Now he bursts out laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are alarmed at Brother Minister's behavior. TWO-SHOT - BETTY AND MALCOLM BETTY If you'll start eating, there is a question I have. Go ahead. Start. He takes a forkful of the salad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Considering today's standards of animal raising and curing meats, I don't fully understand the restriction on pork.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me explain. No. I'll do better than that. I'll show it to you. Scientifically. But it's demonstration purely in the interest of science, you understand?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I understand, Brother Malcolm. Purely scientific. 139
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before a comparative evolutionary display showing the skeletons of various animals, Malcolm is holding forth. Betty is dressed in a vivid, becoming red dress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Notice especially the claw, the jaw and the skull formation. This is the rat. This the mole. Here you have the aardvark and the boar...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...All members of the pig-rodent family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see your point.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So it is not a matter of the breeding conditions or preparation of the meat. The meat itself is foul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . As they saunter out, passing the huge skeletons of prehistoric animals now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could we sit down someplace?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. I've had you on your feet for hours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've been on your feet for days. And didn't even finish your salad. 140
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're the strawberry soda and you're the hot fudge sundae. He plunks down the order before Betty and Malcolm. Malcolm takes a long, long satisfying pull on his straw. Then he sighs: MALCOLM That's something I haven't done in fifteen years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sat down with a pretty girl and had an ice cream soda.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you like it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Delicious. She laughs. He blushes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's talk about you for a change.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's nothing to talk about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 0h, yes, there is. I know a lot about you. Brother Bembry briefed me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh? Purely scientific interest I'm sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're from Detroit, near where I come from. You majored in education at Tuskegee. You're studying nursing and having trouble with your family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can handle it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They want you to quit the Muslims or they won't pay your tuition, isn't that it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have enough worries of your own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, good Sisters are rare. We need every one. Tell me something: how tall are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do you ask?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just an idle question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If it's just idle, I won't answer it. She takes a bite of her sundae.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Brother Bembry says I'm tall enough for a tall man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How old are you, Betty?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a few things you don't know about women, Brother Malcolm. They're possessive and vain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And dogged when I set my mind to something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What have you set your mind to?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Being a good Muslim, a good nurse and a good wife. Malcolm takes a good look at the lovely woman in front of him, then a long sip from his ice cream soda.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brother Malcolm. Betty sees him first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Sidney.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . As Sidney runs to them at the table: SIDNEY Brother Johnson was attacked by the cops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There was a scuffle. The Brother was watching. 141
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .M. Malcolm listening as SEVERAL WITNESSES simultaneously describe the attack. A small angry CROWD has gathered. The most animated one is BENJAMIN, a very dark young black teenager, we will soon meet him later.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cop says, "Move on."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Brother didn't scatter fast enough for the ofay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crack. He bled like a stuck hog.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watcha gonna do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'll rap a little. He's a Muslim. And make a speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Muslims talk a good game, but they never do nothing, unless somebody bothers Muslims. Malcolm's face goes taut. He nods sharply at Sidney, as Benjamin watches them both.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I demand to see Brother Johnson. 142
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .M. Malcolm facing a DESK SERGEANT, TWO UNIFORMED COPS and a PLAINCLOTHESMAN off to one side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who the hell are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm from Muslim Temple 7.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never heard of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is he? The police respond with a squeeze play intended to intimidate Malcolm:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody here by that name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's your name, feller? He feels the power play and stiffens in resistance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Minister Malcolm X. Two witnesses saw him brought in. He was not brought out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard the Sergeant. Outside. Malcolm stands his ground coolly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take a look out that window. I intend to see Brother Johnson. The cops eye each other. Plainclothes walks to the window. 143        EXT. THE STREET OUTSIDE - LATE P.M. Across from the station is a phalanx of some FIFTY MEN of the Fruit of Islam. All are dressed in dark suits with white shirts. They stand in military formation: eyes forward, every face burning. People from the neighborhood have formed a crowd behind and around them. WE MAKE OUT Benjamin among the crowd. 143A        INT. POLICE STATION - NIGHT PLAINCLOTHES Who the hell are they?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brothers of Brother Johnson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eddie, let's see that blotter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - FAVOR MALCOLM As the cops examine the police blotter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. We got a Muslim. The relief must of put it down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you can't see him. You ain't his lawyer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No lawyer, no see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Until I'm satisfied Brother Johnson is receiving proper medical attention, no one will move. Cops eye each other. Plainclothes nods slightly, he has to give in, Malcolm is not playing. 144
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The back of Malcolm's head, as he examines Brother Johnson. As he comes up OUT OF FRAME, WE SEE that Johnson has been badly beaten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only a pig could do a thing like that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watch your tongue, boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you call me boy, you pig. Letting a man bleed like that. Sergeant puts a restraining hand on Plainclothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That man belongs in a hospital. Get an ambulance. Now! 145         EXT. THE STREET - LATER (DARKER) As Johnson's body, on a stretcher, is hurried into an ambulance. The crowd has grown in proportions. There are ad libs: "Goddam pigs," "Damn police brutality," "Least they got him out of the meat house." Malcolm with the Sergeant and a LIEUTENANT, as the ambulance pulls away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, break it up. You got what you wanted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not satisfied. Malcolm starts walking down the center of the street, after the ambulance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To the hospital. The Fruit of Islam fall in behind him, marching slowly. It takes on the start of a march as the neighborhood people fall in behind them. People (especially kids) race with them on the street and on the sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Benjamin fights his way through the crowd trying to walk beside Malcolm, the Brothers in the Fruit stop him and Benjamin drops back. 146
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now the march has taken over the broad avenue. COPS are forced to redirect traffic, holding up crosstown cars as the group walks solemnly by. The people walking behind have swelled it to a huge demonstration. Their faces reflect their anger and their satisfaction that, for once, something is being done about what has happened. 147
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SHOWS the Muslim men in perfect order, calm with their arms folded across their chests, waiting. Their eyes are on Malcolm as he walks toward the hospital entrance. SHOTS --of the growing crowd. --of the nervous cops, including some big brass. --of kids watching from a rooftop. --of Benjamin trying to emulate the Fruit of Islam. 148        EXT. OUTSIDE HARLEM HOSPITAL - NIGHT Malcolm is standing in front of the Fruit of Islam men, as HIGHRANKING POLICE OFFICER GREEN comes over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, that's enough. I want these people moved out of here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're all disciplined men. They're doing nothing except waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The unruly crowd behind the Fruit of Islam. They are restive, milling, ugly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's your headache, Captain. And if he dies, I pity you. 149
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'll live. He's getting the best care we can give.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Doctor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had to put a plate in his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You bastards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, okay. Now disperse this mob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's clear the decision is in one man's hands, Malcolm's. CLOSE SHOT - MALCOLM He makes a gesture with his hand, the Fruit of Islam disperse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . People moving away, going home. Only one person remains from the Fruit of Islam and the crowd, it's Benjamin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's too much power for one man to have. 149A
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone is in a somber mood over the evening's events. ANGLE - TABLE Malcolm sits with Brothers Earl and Sidney.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brother Minister, we need to strike back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Put fear into those devils.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to also, but until we are instructed by the Messenger to do so, we will just wait and pray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm tired of praying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's enough, Brother Earl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Benjamin comes into the cafeteria and everyone looks at him. He sees Malcolm sitting and moves toward his table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brothers Sidney and Earl get up to intercept him but Malcolm waves him through. Benjamin stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit down, son. Malcolm pours some cream into his cup of black coffee, then also some white sugar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is only one thing I like integrated. My coffee. Benjamin laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What can I do for you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. X, I was out there tonight. I saw what you did. I want to be a Muslim. I ain't never seen a Negro stand up to the police like that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They exchange dubious looks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know what it means to be a true Muslim? Benjamin hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not exactly, but I want to be one, like you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I admire your enthusiasm but you should never join any organization without first checking it out thoroughly. Benjamin is crushed and he starts to get up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We need more young warriors like yourself, stick around and we shall see if your heart is true.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. X, I won't make you out a liar. 180
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: #1 - DETROIT - DAY CLOSE - NEWSPAPER HEADLINE (DAILY NEWS) MALCOLM X WINS $70,000 JUDGMENT FOR BEATEN NEGRO An AIDE of Elijah puts down the newspaper and shakes Malcolm's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Honorable Elijah Muhammad would like to see you now. 151
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elijah is sweeping the floor with a plain hand broom. Malcolm enters the room, is surprised and waits at the door. The two are alone together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I surprise you, let me explain. Menial work teaches us humility.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me do it then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, each of us must relearn that work is the only worthwhile thing. Allah has given you a great gift. Use it wisely, never forgetting that we are nothing, while He is all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Allah Akbar. The sweeping done, they stand together near a table at a window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tonight I shall introduce you as my National Representative. It will be a difficult task. Your assignment is to build temples all over this nation. More work than you have ever done in your life and you will be in the public eye. My son, beware of those cameras, they are just as bad as a narcotic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and OTHERS come into the room now. They are listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, the white devil will watch your every step. Even your own Brothers will become jealous, and hostile, go slowly. So I offer you a parable -- regarding your work. Elijah picks up a glass and sets it before Malcolm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here is a glass, dirty and its water foul. If you offer it to the people and they have no choice, they must drink out of it. But if you present them with this glass-- He is holding a clean glass, with clear water in it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: --and let them make their decision, they will choose the pure vessel. Islam is the only religion which addresses the needs and problems of the so-called Negro, especially in the ghettos -- Islam is the only way out from drugs, crime, unemployment, prostitution, alcohol, gambling, fornication and adultery. Elijah holds up the clear glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This sweet, gentle man gave me the truth from his own mouth. And I adored him, in the sense of the Latin root of the word. Adorare, to worship and to fear. He was the first man I ever feared -- not fear such as the one has of a gun but the fear one has of the power of the sun, I pledged myself to him, even if it cost me my life. 152
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Betty is administering to a PATIENT, as a phone is heard ringing. It's answered. ANOTHER NURSE motions Betty to the phone. She finishes with her patient and goes quickly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sister Betty?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. 153
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: m in Detroit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At a gas station. (a beat) Will you marry me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you hear what I said?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes I did. Did you hear my answer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think so. Can you catch a plane?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Did you eat?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you. 154
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EXT.
location: A PAY PHONE AT A GAS STATION

direction.raw_text: Betty and Malcolm sit on the floor in the dimlit room, very close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It won't be easy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just hold me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It will be rough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hush your mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be away a lot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're with me even when you're away. He embraces her. Then Betty laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never told you, but when I first saw you on the podium, cleaning your glasses, I felt sorry for you. Nobody as young as you should be that serious. But I don't think that anymore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The simplest thing in the world: I want to have a lot of babies with you. Dear Heart, I love you. Full embrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're waiting on you folks. You trying to starve us? 155

direction.raw_text: Malcolm has just cut the cake and handed a slice to Betty. Amid laughter and great warmth, Sidney unfurls the front page of the _Messenger_, the Muslim newspaper. Headline reads: "MALCOLM X WEDS BETTY SAUNDERS." Betty kisses her husband and Bembry, Lorraine, Earl, Sidney, Peter and VARIOUS BROTHERS AND SISTERS applaud. We notice the subtle change in the apartment: it is more comfortable; there is even evidence of some small luxury: a TV set, a new settee, etc. 156

direction.raw_text: Malcolm is speaking to a GOOD SIZED AUDIENCE:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I must emphasize at the outstart, that the Honorable Elijah Muhammad is not a politician, so I'm not here this afternoon as a Republican, nor a Democrat, not as a Mason nor an Elk, not as a Christian nor a Jew, not as a Catholic nor a Protestant, not as a Baptist nor a Methodist, not even as an American. For if I was an American the problem that confronts our people today would not exist. So I stand here as what I was when I was born: A BLACK MAN!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (contd) Before there were any such things as Democrats or Republicans, we were black. Before there were any such things as Masons or Elks, we were black. Before there were any such things as Jews or Christians, we were black people. In fact long before there was ever any such place as America, we were black people... And after America has long passed from the scene there will still be BLACK PEOPLE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is neatly dressed in white shirt, jacket and tie, a fine young Muslim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take your time. 157
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Honorable Elijah Muhammad sits on the stage to the right of Malcolm. This is a larger audience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of black people does the Honorable Elijah Muhammad speak for? Black people who are jobless... the black masses who are poor, hungry, and angry, the black masses who are dissatisfied with the slums and ghettos in which we have been forced to live... the black masses who are tired of listening to the promises of white politicians to correct the miserable living conditions that exist in our community... the black masses that are sick of the inhuman acts of bestial brutality practiced by these semi-savage white policemen that patrol our community, like the occupation forces of a conquering enemy army... the black masses who are fed up with the anemic, Uncle Tom leadership set up by the white man to act as a spokesman for our people and to KEEP US SATISFIED AND PACIFIED WITH NOTHING!
direction.name: direction

result.heading: KEEP US SATISFIED AND PACIFIED WITH NOTHING

direction.raw_text: - REACTIONS CLOSE - MALCOLM MALCOLM If the black man cannot go back to his own people and his own land, Elijah Muhammad is asking that a part of the United States be separated and given to the Muslims so they can live separately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (contd) The Honorable Elijah Muhammad is the only man the white people can deal with in the solving of problems of the so-called Negro...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (contd) ...as Elijah Muhammad knows his problems. 158         INT. BETTY'S BEDROOM - NIGHT A modest room. direction.raw_text: Malcolm sits in front of a television screen and watches the evening news. direction.raw_text: The white people who are guilty of white supremacy try and hide their own guilt by accusing the Honorable Elijah Muhammad of teaching black supremacy when he tries to uplift the mentality, the social, and economic condition of black people in this country. And the Jews, who have been guilty of exploiting the black people economically, civilly, and otherwise, hide their guilt by accusing the Honorable Elijah Muhammad of being anti-Semitic simply because he teaches our people to go into business for ourselves and trying to take over the economic leadership in our own community. The black people in this country have been the victims of violence at the hands of the white man for 400 years, and following the ignorant Negro preachers, we have thought that it was God-like to turn the other cheek to the brute that was brutalizing us. 100 years ago they use to put on a white sheet and use a bloodhound against Negroes. Today they've taken off sheets and put on police uniforms, they've traded in the bloodhounds for police dogs. And just as Uncle Tom back during slavery used to keep the Negroes from resisting the bloodhounds or resisting the Ku Klux Klan by telling them to love their enemy or pray for those who use them as spitefully today. The Honorable Elijah Muhammad is showing black people that just as the white man and every other person on this earth has God given rights, natural rights, civil rights, and any other kind of rights that you can think of when it comes to defending himself. 159 A-C
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TV STUDIO CLOSE SHOT - MALCOLM'S FACE With a studio mike around his neck, he's on a panel show. ANGLE - MODERATOR MODERATOR Mr. X, before we start our discussion tonight -- The Black Muslims: Hate Mongers -- would you mind explaining for us the meaning of your name, which is the letter X.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Opposing Malcolm is DR. PAYSON, a NAACP-type NEGRO. CLOSE - MALCOLM MALCOLM Yes sir. As you know, during slavery time, the slavemasters named most of the so-called Negroes in America after themselves. Mr. Elijah Muhammad teaches us once you come into the knowledge of Islam, you replace your slave name with an X. Since we've been disconnected, cut off from our Eastern culture for so long that we don't know the names we originally had, we will use X until we get back to the East.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Now Dr. Payson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PAYSON DR. PAYSON Mr. X is a demagogue. He has no place to go, so he exaggerates. He's a disservice to every good law-abiding Negro in the country. Can I ask you a question?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : - DR. PAYSON MALCOLM Please, go ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Malcolm X, why do you teach black supremacy? Why do you teach hate?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For the white man to ask the black man if he hates him is just like the rapist asking the raped, or the wolf asking the sheep, "Do you hate me!" The white man is in no moral position to accuse anyone of hate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Certainly, Mr. X, you must admit there has been progress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll talk about "progress" in a minute, but let me finish with my brother. Malcolm gestures to the Negro panelist.  The BLACK MEMBERS of the TV audience are lapping it up. Betty and Earl also sit in the TV studio audience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop me if I'm wrong. I "polarize the community." I "erroneously appraise the racial picture."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You put it very well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You left one phrase out. Another educated Kneegrew said to me and I quote: "Brother Malcolm oversimplifies the dynamic interstices of the Negro subculture." Would you agree?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Entirely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I have this to say. Do you know what a Negro with a B.A., an M.A. and a Ph.D. is called -- by the white man? I'll tell you. He's called a nigger. There is some blanching and guffawing from the audience. The moderator is totally embarrassed, Betty roars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'm not finished. To understand this man-- He points a sharp finger at the Negro Panelist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: --you must know that historically there are two kinds of slaves. House Negroes and Field Negroes. The house Negro lived in the big house; he dressed pretty good; he ate pretty good and he loved the master. Yeah, he loved him more than the master loved himself. If the master's house caught fire, he'd be the first to put the blaze out. If the master got sick, he'd say: "What's a matter, boss; we sick?" WE sick! If someone said to him, "Let's run away and escape. Let's separate." He'd say, "Man, are you crazy? What's better than what I got here?" That was the House Negro. In those days he was called the House Nigger. Well, that's what we call them today because we still got a lot of House Niggers running around. There is applause from the blacks in the audience. Moderator tries to regain control. 159D
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is enjoying this display by his prize student, the CAMERA PANS to a CLOSE SHOT of BEMBRY and the same cannot be said. 159E
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think, perhaps, Dr. Payson has something to--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you want to hear about the Field Nigger?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let him finish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Now the Negro in the field caught hell all day long. He was beaten by the master; he lived in a shack, wore castoff clothes and hated his master. If the house caught fire, he'd pray for a wind. If the master got sick, he'd pray that he'd die. And if you said to him, "Let's go, let's separate", he'd yell, "Yeah, man, any place is better than this." You've got a lot of Field Negroes in America today. I'm one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: --there's another one. The majority of black Americans today are Field Negroes. They don't talk about OUR progress, about OUR government, OUR navy, OUR astronauts. Hell, they won't even let you near the plant. 159F
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bembry turns off the TV set and he commences to plant the seeds of "betrayal."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your holy apostle, dear Messenger, I am your true servant and the brothers asked me to tell you Malcolm is getting too much press. The brothers think he thinks _he_ is the Nation of Islam, that he has aspirations to lead the Nation. It was you who made Malcolm the man he is. You lifted him out of the darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go and tell the brothers what Brother Minister is doing, has done, has been of great benefit to the Nation.

result.heading: THE RISE OF MALCOLM X EXT

direction.raw_text: Brother Man, put that bottle down, take that poison away from your lips. That's what the devil wants you to do, stay high, out of your natural mind. I know, I've been there. He walks; they follow. 159I        --Malcolm walking in Harlem, urging people to lift themselves up, come to the meetings, etc. 159J

direction.raw_text: I'll have it tomorrow.

direction.raw_text: - SLUMS, TENEMENTS, GARBAGE, RATS MALCOLM (contd) Poor education, you only work on poor paying jobs and that enables you to live again in a poor neighborhood. 159N

direction.raw_text: Mr. X, I've read some of your speeches and I honestly believe a lot of what you say has truth to it. I have a good heart. I'm a good person despite my whiteness. What can the good white people like myself, who are not prejudiced, or racist, what can we do to help the cause?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stares at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is absolutely crushed and runs away in tears. 161         INT. HARVARD LAW SCHOOL - DAY Speaking to a packed STUDENT AUDIENCE. MALCOLM ...My high school was the black ghetto of Roxbury. My college was the streets of Harlem, and I took my masters in prison. If you look out the window-- 161A

direction.raw_text: --you can see my burglary hangout. I lived like an animal. Had it not been for the Honorable Elijah Muhammad I would surely be in an insane asylum or dead.

direction.raw_text: Mr. Muhammad is trying to get us on God's side, so God will be on our side to help us fight our battles. When Negroes stop getting drunk, stop being addicted to drugs, stop fornicating and committing adultery. When we get off the welfare, then we'll be MEN. Earn what you need for your family, then your family respects you. They'll be proud to say "That's my father." She's proud to say "That's my husband..." Father means you're taking care of those children. Just 'cause you made them that don't mean you're a father. Anybody can make a baby, but anybody can't take care of them. Anyone can go and get a woman but anybody can't take care of a woman. This is the type of teaching that the honorable Elijah Muhammad teaches us so we can build the moral fiber of our people.

direction.raw_text: Malcolm is talking before an all-black audience. It is the largest rally yet; the hall is packed to the rafters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have built temples in Boston, in Detroit, in Atlanta, Philadelphia, Washington -- 100 temples in fifty states. From a handful we have grown to scores of thousands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: selling _The Messenger_, faces of Fruit of Islam near the podium; Lorraine, Sidney, Earl, Benjamin, and Bembry. For the first time a new note is seen in Bembry's face: reserve bordering on resentment. When others around him cheer Malcolm, Bembry is cool. Sidney notices this from his father, but makes no comment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Honorable Elijah Muhammad teaches us that God is now about to establish a kingdom on this earth based on brotherhood and [...] against peace, his history on this earth has proved that. Nowhere in history has he been brotherly toward anyone. The only time he has been brotherly toward you is when he can use you, when he can exploit you, when he can oppress you, when you will submit to him. And since his own history makes him unqualified to be an inhabitant or a citizen in a kingdom of brotherhood, the Honorable Elijah Muhammad teaches us that God is about to eliminate that particular race from this earth. So since they are due for elimination, we don't want to be with them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - CROWD CLOSE - MALCOLM MALCOLM (contd) If the so-called Negro were American citizens we wouldn't have a race problem. If the Emancipation Proclamation was authentic, you wouldn't have a race problem. If the 13th, 14th, and 15th amendments to the Constitution was authentic, you wouldn't have a race problem. If the Supreme Court desegregation decision was authentic, you wouldn't have a race problem. All of this is hypocrisy. These Negro leaders have been telling the white man everything is all right, everything is under control. And they've been telling the white man that Mr. Muhammad is wrong, don't listen to him. But everything Mr. Muhammad has been saying is going to come to pass is now coming to pass and now the Negro leaders are standing up saying that we are about to have a racial explosion. We're going to have a racial explosion and that's more dangerous than an atomic explosion.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: COMPLETE SEPARATION IS THE ONLY SOLUTION TO THE BLACK AND WHITE PROBLEM IN THIS COUNTRY

direction.raw_text: (contd) It's going to explode because black people are dissatisfied. They're dissatisfied now not only with the white man, but with these Negroes who have been sitting around here posing as leaders and spokesmen for black people. Anytime you put too many sparks around a powder keg, the thing is going to explode and if the thing that explodes is still inside the house, then the house will be destroyed. So the Honorable Elijah Muhammad is telling the white man get this powder keg out of your house, let the black people in this country separate from him while there's still time. And if the black man is allowed to separate and go on onto some land of his own, where he can solve his problems, then there won't be any explosion. COMPLETE SEPARATION IS THE ONLY SOLUTION TO THE BLACK AND WHITE PROBLEM IN THIS COUNTRY!!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A wave of cheers as people explode. 163

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, what's the matter with you? Wake up! Are you so dedicated that you have blinded yourself? Are you so committed you cannot face the truth? direction.raw_text: Do you know what Bembry is doing? You're so blind, everyone can see this but you!!!

direction.raw_text: Because 1964 threatens to be a very explosive year on the racial front, and because I myself intend to be very active in every phase of the American Negro struggle for HUMAN RIGHTS, I have called this press conference, this morning in order to clarify my own position in the struggle -- especially in regards to politics and nonviolence. In the past I thought the thoughts, spoke the words of the Honorable Elijah Muhammad, that day is over. From now on I speak my own words, and think my own thoughts. Internal differences within the Nation of Islam forced me out of it. I did not leave of my own free will. But now that it has happened, I intend to make the most of it. Now that I have more independence of action, I intend to use a more flexible approach toward working with others to get a solution to this problem. I do not pretend to be a divine man, but I do believe in divine guidance, divine power, and in the fulfillment of divine prophecy. I am not educated, nor am I an expert in any particular field, but I am sincere, and my sincerity is my credentials. I'm not out to fight other Negro leaders or organizations. We must find a common solution, to a common problem. I am going to organize and head a new mosque in New York City, known as the Muslim Mosque, Inc. This gives us a religious base, and the spiritual force necessary to rid our people of the vices that destroy the moral fiber of our community. Our political philosophy will be black nationalism. Our economic and social philosophy will be black nationalism. The Muslim Mosque, Inc. will remain wide open for ideas and financial aid from all quarters. Whites can help us, but they can't join us. There can be no black-white unity until there is first some black unity. A host of questions fired all at once: How many of Elijah's followers will join you? etc, etc, etc. Malcolm calms them:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is one further preparation I need. It is a return to the source of our great religion. I will make a pilgrimage to Mecca. 174

direction.raw_text: . MECCA - DAY/NIGHT --Malcolm, wearing the garb of a pilgrim, walks with a VAST THRONG OF OTHERS, similarly clad, around the Great Temple. He wears two white towels, one over his loins, the other over his neck and shoulder, leaving the right arm and shoulder bare. He wears simple sandals. The other pilgrims are of various colors: from white, to yellow, to darkest black. 177A         --Malcolm and OTHER PILGRIMS kneeling together on a praying rug. 177B        --Malcolm and SEVERAL WHITE PILGRIMS eating Muslim-style; breaking a chicken and shaking it. 177C        --Malcolm and OTHERS walking around the Great Kaaba, a black stone set in the middle of the Great Mosque. He falls to his knees. WE SEE what he describes:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Today, with thousands of others, I proclaimed God's greatness in the Holy City of Mecca. Wearing the Ihram garb I made my seven circuits around the Kaaba; I drank from the well of Zem Zem; I prayed to Allah from Mt. Ararat where the Ark landed. It was the only time in my life that I stood before the Creator of all and felt like a complete human being. 178
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You may be shocked by these words, but I have eaten from the same plate, drunk from the same glass and prayed to the same God with fellow Muslims whose eyes were blue, whose hair was blond and whose skin was the whitest of whites. And we are brothers, truly; people of all colors and races believing in One God and one humanity. Once before, in prison, the truth came and blinded me. It has happened again... 179

direction.raw_text: . MALCOLM'S HOME - NIGHT Betty is with Brothers Earl, Benjamin 2X, and the children. There are now four including another BABY - GAMILAH MALCOLM'S VOICE In the past, I have permitted myself to be used to make sweeping indictments of all white people, and these generalizations have caused injuries to some white folks who did not deserve them. Because of the spiritual rebirth which I was blessed to undergo as a result of my pilgrimage to the Holy City of Mecca, I no longer subscribe to sweeping indictments of one race. I intend to be careful not to sentence anyone who has not been proven guilty. I'm not a racist and do not subscribe to any of the tenets of racism. In all honesty and sincerity it can be stated that I wish nothing but freedom, justice and equality: life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness for all people. 179A

Muslims look upon themselves as human beings, as part of the human family and therefore look upon all other segments of the human family as part of that same family. Today my friends are black, brown, red, yellow and white.

direction.raw_text: The place is filled. Betty and the girls sit in a boxed-off section near the platform. Malcolm's bodyguards stand on and around the stand. Benjamin 2X is finishing up his speech when Malcolm walks onto the stage and sits down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Make it plain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now, without further remarks, I present to you one who is willing to put himself on the line for you--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - BETTY AND THE KIDS CLOSE - THOMAS HAYER CLOSE - WILBUR KINLEY CLOSE - LEON DAVIS CLOSE - BEN THOMAS CLOSE - WILLIAM X CLOSE - MALCOLM X CLOSE - BENJAMIN 2X BENJAMIN 2X (contd) --a man who would give his life for you. I want you to hear, to listen, to understand one who is a Trojan for the black man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A roar greets Malcolm's intro. He shakes hands with Benjamin 2X, then steps toward the podium.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts to rearrange his 3 x 5 index cards in his hands.

direction.raw_text: Brothers and Sisters, Wa-Salaam Alaikum.

direction.raw_text: Alaikum Wa-Salaam.

direction.raw_text: There is a commotion in the rear of the audience. BENJAMIN THOMAS Git your hand out of my pocket. The bodyguards move toward the rear. CLOSE - MALCOLM MALCOLM Hold it, brothers. Don't get excited. Let's cool it--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stands up from the fourth row with 12-gauge sawed-off shotgun blasting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Throws up his hands, grabs his chest and is knocked backward. SHOTS - PURE PANDEMONIUM People hit the floor, knock over chairs, stampede for the exits. ANGLE - BACK OF AUDITORIUM Wilbur Kinley ignites a smoke bomb. ANGLE - FIRST RUN Thomas Hayer and Leon Davis stand up, run toward the stage, and empty their .45's and Luger into the fallen body of Malcolm. ANGLE - BETTY She is on the floor covering her children. ANGLE - AISLE Hayer and Davis charge up the aisle toward the rear exit, shooting at the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stands in Hayer's way, Hayer fires, he turns, the bullet misses and the bodyguard gets off a shot which hits Hayer in the leg.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stumbles momentarily, then limps on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hayer is running down the staircase when he is tripped, and goes flying through the air to the bottom of the landing. The crowd starts to beat the shit out of him, kicking him in the head, etc., they're about to tear him apart from limb to limb when a PATROLMAN enters with gun drawn. He shoots gun into air and the crowd backs off and he takes custody of Hayer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of Malcolm's bodyguards, BROTHER GENE, is over him, giving him mouth-to-mouth resuscitation. Brother Gene stops, Betty moves in and hugs her dying husband.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Somebody call an ambulance. Somebody call an ambulance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: walk in like it's a spring Sunday stroll in Central Park.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes are glazed over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They killed him. They killed him. 200        SHOT - BROTHERS EARL AND BENJAMIN 2X SITTING ON STAGE 200A        SHOT - MALCOLM IS RUSHED ON A STRETCHER TO HOSPITAL NEXT DOOR SHOT - HOSPITAL SPOKESPERSON HOSPITAL SPOKESPERSON The person you know as Malcolm is no more. 200B

result.heading: THE STUNNED FACES OF BLACK PEOPLE OUTSIDE THE AUDUBON BALLROOM

direction.raw_text: speaking behind the above:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here at this final hour, in this quiet place, Harlem has come to bid farewell to one of its brightest hopes, extinguished now and gone from us forever. 200C
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of the long line of people outside the funeral parlor, waiting to see Malcolm's body, where it lies before burial.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For Harlem is where he worked, and where he struggled and fought. His home of homes, where his heart was and where his people are. And it is therefore most fitting that we meet once again in Harlem to share these last moments with him. For Harlem has ever been gracious to those who loved her, have fought for her and defended her honor even to death. It is not in the memory of man that this beleaguered, unfortunate but nonetheless proud community has found a braver, more gallant young champion than this Afro-American who lies before us unconquered still. Many will ask what Harlem finds to honor in this stormy, controversial and bold young captain and we will smile and we will answer and say unto them: 2OOD  SHOTS - FACES OF HARLEM - PRESENT DAY - THE 90'S Ordinary PEOPLE in ordinary pursuits of life, BLACK PEOPLE still struggling to stay afloat in a racist WHITE AMERICA that does not have their best interests at hand -- 8 years of Reagan and now at least 4 years of Bush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you ever talk to Brother Malcolm? Did you have him smile at you? Did you ever listen to him? Did he ever really do a mean thing? Was he ever associated with violence or any public disturbance? 200E
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - STREET SIGN - MALCOLM X BOULEVARD - HARLEM 200F        SHOT - YOUNG AFRO-CENTRIC TEENAGERS WITH MALCOLM X T-SHIRTS, HATS, JACKETS, JEWELRY, ETC.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For if you did, you would know him and if you knew him, you would know why we must honor him. 200G
direction.name: direction

result.heading: NEWSREEL FOOTAGE OF THE _REAL_ MALCOLM X OSSIE DAVIS'S VOICE

direction.raw_text: - NEWSREEL FOOTAGE OF THE _REAL_ MALCOLM X OSSIE DAVIS'S VOICE (contd) Malcolm was our manhood, our living black manhood. That was his meaning to his people and in honoring him we honor the best in ourselves. 200H
direction.name: direction
